House in committee on Bill (No. 53) respecting the Canadian Northern Railway Company.-Mr. Davis.
On section 4,

Mr. Chairman, before this clause passes, as we have now the Minister of Railways and Canals (Hon. Mr. Blair) in his seat, and as that gentleman was not present during the consideration of private Bills on Friday night, I would like to state one or two objections I have to this Bill. In the first place, I object to the Bill on general principles. The Bill authorizes the construction of 5,000 or
6,000	miles of railway, and this power, to be given in any one charter, is altogether too great. I object also to the Bill because it authorizes the construction of certain branch lines, but the descriptions of these lines are so indefinite that we do not know where the roads are going to run. But, my most serious objection to the Bill is the fact that by its terms it entirely controls the only two available passes through the Rocky Mountains. These are the Pine River and the Yellow Head passes. There was an engineer who went through the Pine River Pass about twenty-five years ago, and a gentleman named Mr. Hunter also went through about twenty years ago. Neither one of these gentlemen reported on the feasibility of this pass for a railway. There is no information on that point as far as I can learn. I submit, Mr. Chairman, that the hon. Minister of Railways and Canals should take steps to see, if any other transcontinental road should endeavour to get through the mountains as there are no other passes available, that they should have running powers over the line in one of these two passes. I notice that the Board of Trade held a meeting in Winnipeg a few days ago to discuss a resolution sent to it by the Halifax Board of Trade dealing with the Intercolonial Railway. I may say that the Winnipeg Board of Trade represents practically all the large and influential corporations loaning moneys on the prairies. That board took the ground that a commission should be appointed to look into the question as to whether the Intercolonial Railway could be made a factor in the transportation of that country, and if it could that it might be feasible on the part of the government to extend that system to the Pacific coast to serve as a feeder for the road. That proposition was very

speakerposition: Prime Minister; President of the Privy Council
speechtext:
fully discussed by several gentlemen who are deeply interested in that country, and the partner of the hon. member for West Toronto (Mr. Osier), Mr. Nanton, seconded the resolution. I am not going to say whether this is feasible or not, but, if it is feasible and if it should transpire that it should be necessary in the future for the government to extend the road to the Pacific coast, they should adopt the policy of reserving these passes with that end in view. But, there is another factor in connection with this charter to which I wish to draw attention. As you are aware, Mr. Chairman, a bargain was entered into between the Manitoba government and the Northern Pacific Railway, which bargain was passed also by this government. That arrangement was something like this : The Manitoba government leased from the Northern . Pacific Railway Company for a period of years the company's lines in the province of Manitoba, having a mileage of 350 miles for which they were to pay an annual rental of $210,000. The Manitoba government released those lines to the Canadian Northern Railway Company, and a bargain was made that on certain bonds issued by the Canadian Northern line the government were to guarantee interest to the extent of $20,000 a mile on 300 miles, and on certain other bonds covering 1,000 miles of road, the Manitoba government were to guarantee interest at the rate of $10,000 per mile. That is 1,300 miles in all on which interest is guaranteed. Out of the receipts of the railway company they were to pay, first, the running expenses of the road, secondly, the $210,000 rental to the Northern Pacific, and thirdly, they were to pay interest on these bonds, amounting to about $14,000,000, but in default the Manitoba government had to pay any arrears of interest accrued. Should there be a surplus at the end of two years that might be applied to a reduction of freight rates. This was the consideration for which the Manitoba government became the endorser of the bonds of the company so that the farmers of the western part of Manitoba should get a material reduction in freight rates. The reduction was to be 2 cents a bushel on wheat on the first year's operation. If the road proved a paying concern, there was to be a further reduction in the rates. This Bill goes on to say that they should have power to bond the road for $25,000 per mile, not only on any lines to be constructed, but also on the lines now constructed, and the question arises:	Is that $15,000 extra per mile to
be in addition to the 1,300 miles for which the Manitoba government are responsible as endorser ? If it is, it seems that in addition to guaranteeing the interest on what is provided for in the agreement now that government will have to become responsible for the interest on $15,000 per mile extra and there will be no opportunity of gaining any further reduction in freight rates.
What is the bonding power on the 1,300 miles that have been already constructed ?
I am sorry that I cannot give the hon. gentleman the information he asks me for.
If they bond it for $25,000 per mile and it is completed it would not affect the matter.

I suppose not. But the Manitoba government assumed respons-bility for $10,000 a mile on a portion and $20,000 on another portion. I may not be correct in my contention, but I want to have It shown that I am not correct. I want to see that the Manitoba government will not have to guarantee interest on $25,000 per mile instead of $10,000. I want to see that the farmers of Manitoba who are supposed to get the benefit of that road will not have to pay interest on that extra bonding per mile. It is the duty of the Minister of Railways to clear up the point. He was thoroughly cognisant of the matter when it came before the Railway Committee and I have no doubt he will be able to explain.

The hon. member from Selkirk (Mr. McCreary) has invited my attention to some provisions of this Bill, and he particularly mentions the fact that it is proposed to construct an enormous mileage which he thinks we are not justified in empowering the company to construct. The hon. gentleman said that if this Bill passes the company will have authority to occupy not only the Yellow Head Pass but also the Pine River Pass under existing legislation. It will be remembered by members of the Railway Committee that two or three times I called the attention of the committee to the extended character of this proposed undertaking, and I mentioned that the company were asking to occupy a very great deal of territory. As far as my observations then impressed themselves on the committee the result was that considerable lengths of mileage which were embraced in the original Bill were stricken off, and it appeared to be the sense of the committee that the balance of the Bill should stand. I did not carry the controversy further ; I do not propose to continue the controversy now. I called explicit attention to the very point which the hon. gentleman (Mr. McCreary) has dwelt upon, and the committee after listening to the arguments on both sides concluded that it was not improper legislation. Considerable respect is due to the decision of the committee with respect to all of these Bills, and unless the circumstances are of an extraordinary character, or unless something has been done under a misapprehension of the facts I think it is better to consider the decision of the committee as approaching finality. What my hon. friend (Mr. McCreary) has said with regard to the necessity of providing that running powers shall be secured to any 841
railway that may desire to use any of these passes, is covered by existing legislation completely. We would have added it to this Bill if it were necessary, but it is not necessary. The hon. gentleman seems to be under the impression that we have no information in the department as to the character of this Pine River Pass from a railway point of view. The hon. gentleman is not fully informed with respect to that, because my deputy tells me that the records of the department show that a very careful survey was made of the Pine River Pass, with the result that the opinion of the engineer, Sir Sanford Fleming was, that there was only room for one track through it. While that is the case, some one must build the track. It is quite immaterial it appears to me by what company the track is built, because there is ample power in the government under existing legislation to secure to any companies who desire to use the same pass, all the rights which they will need for such a purpose.
With reference to the effect of this legislation upon the contract entered into by the Manitoba government with the Canada Northen Railway ; that point occurred to my mind before this question was disposed of in the committee, and I made such inquiries that I felt were necessary. I did not see how it would be possible for this legislation to enlarge or to restrict in any degree the contract as it affects the existing bonds which were already issued ; and upon inquiry I was very well satisfied that my opinion in that regard was well founded. I think I can safely assure the hon. gentleman that he need have no anxiety on that account.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS (Hon. A. G. Blair).

speechtext:
I would like to say that while I would be only too glad to accept the assurances of the Minister of Railways on the subject of the responsibility likely to be laid upon the province of Manitoba by this legislation it is not altogether clear to my mind that the province Is not placed at a disadvantage by it. J must admit my lack of legal training, and therefore that I am at a disadvantage in discussing this question. But it is an important question. We are going to do something that we cannot undo, and it is well that we should proceed with the fullest information, even to those of us who are not thoroughly versed in legal questions. The Manitoba government lies under its present responsibility in respect of the Canadian Northern Railway because of legislation by this parliament. That responsibility is limited to a certain amount. This parliament by legislation now in hand permits the adding of a certain load of responsibility, not on the province but on the company. This brings up the question as to whether the company, by reason of this legislation would not be at liberty to provide for the discharge of the interest upon the additional bonds before giving that advantage to the people of Manitoba which they

expect because of the responsibility they have assumed. That is to say, that the company being only allowed to provide for a bonded liability of $10,000 a mile ; this legislation will permit them to provide for a bonded liability of $25,000 per mile. It is an arguable question it seems to me, whether they will not be able to hold that legislation up as a defence for paying interest on that additional $15,000 per mile before discharging their obligations to the people of Manitoba in regard to the reduction of rates. The fact of giving them the privilege to place these additional bonds upon the road may be used by them as a protection against the terms of their present agreement with the province of Manitoba. I may be wrong in that and I may be right ; but I would make this suggestion :	That the
lines in the province of Manitoba, or the lines covered by the agreement with the province of Manitoba, be exempted from the provisions of this section. Then there will be no question about it. Then the province will be perfectly safe. We would know certainly that we had done no harm anyway, and I can see no objection to that provision being made.
Further I would like to say, that the idea that a railway company pays the interest on its own bonds is now exploded. The company does not pay anything. It is the people who use the road that pay the interest. They pay it through the rates which it costs them to have their traffic carried. If the company is permitted by parliament to bond its line through the prairies of the Saskatchewan valley at the rate of $25,000 per mile, the future population of that valley must pay that interest, if the interest is to be paid. The government in exercising Its authority as to control of rates must take into consideration the fact that it authorized the issue of these bonds to the amount of $25,000 per mile, and thereby became a party to the charging of rates sufficient to earn interest on that amount of bonds., I claim that it is the duty of parliament to restrict the issue of bonds on a railroad to the necessities of the case. It is necessary to do that if parliament is to exercise effective control of the rates to be afterwards charged on that road by means of a railway commission or by any other means. If the bonding power of $10,000 per mile is sufficient to construct the line of the Canadian Northern through the prairie sections of the province of Manitoba. $10,000 a mile should be sufficient to enable them to construct through the prairie regions of the Saskatchewan-if not absolutely then aproximately. The fact that they were willing to make a bargain with the province of Manitoba to build a line through the prairie sections of that province on a bonding privilege of $10,000 per mile is absolute proof that the bonding power of $25,000 per mile applied to prairie construction through the Saskatchewan valley is needlessly large, and as a matter of fact lays Mr. OLIVER.
a burden of future taxation upon the future population of that country, for which, they, nor we, nor any one else outside the men composing the company, receive any value whatever. I would ask the Minister of Railways and the House to protect beyond question the province of Manitoba against any additional obligation, and further to protect the future interests of the western country by restricting the bonding powers of this railway to the necessities of the case. The experience of this country in the past proves that such safeguard is necessary, in order that the country may get the proper benefit from the expenditure made in aid of railway construction.

I was in the Railway Committee when this clause was passed, but I have just had the explanation of the Minister of Railways that it does not interfere with the bonds already issued. If that be so, there can be no objection to it. But taking the wording of the clause, * The company may from time to time issue and secure by mortgage, bonds, debentures, or other securities for the purpose of the acquisition by purchase, &c., there is nothing to show that the bonds so authorized to be issued will not rank; pari passu with those already issued.
Those already issued are secured by a first mortgage under the agreement with the province of Manitoba.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: I do not remember at present how these bonds stand, but I was simply pointing out what appeared to be the effect of this clause. Even if the bonds already issued be secured by a first mortgage, the House should still be careful to see that by this Act we are not in any way taking from their precedence. That could be guarded against by providing an additional clause, which would give these bonds already issued priority beyond doubt over those authorized to be issued.

I do not see how there can be any doubt as to the position of the bonds now issued. They are the subject matter of a special contract between the Manitoba government and the Canadian Northern Railway. The papers were before us last session, and most of us will remember that a mortgage was executed by the company, whereby the bonds then issued, up to the amount of $10,000 per mile, were made the first lien on the road. No authority which may subsequently be granted by parliament to issue additional bonds could possibly change the position of those previously issued. The bonds now authorized will have to follow and be a second security. We have not, are not giving them any priority, nor are we putting them on an equal footing. Therefore, whoever holds the existing mortgage, holds the property in security for the bonds issued prior to

this arrangement. The Manitoba government no doubt have been made thoroughly acquainted with the character of this proposed legislation, and if there were anything in it which might infringe on their rights, they would have quickly called our attention to it.
In reply to the hon. member for Alberta (Mr. Oliver) I may say that it was the understanding of the Railway Committee, when that committee agreed to report the Bill, that I should take the third and fourth clauses into my consideration. I had called the attention of the committee to the very large capitalization powers, and said that these two clauses might well receive further consideration, and that if the committee were content, I would look into the matter and suggest any change, and in the meantime they could report the Bill. My hon. friend is therefore right in asking me for some explanation why I have advised that the bonding power should be retained at the amount first stated. It is all very well for my hon. friend to talk about the cost of the construction, but taking the least costly of the railways mentioned in the present Bill, I had inquiries made by the best of my engineering staff, and they told me that to build this road and to bridge it- and there will have to be two very expensive bridges across the Saskatchewan river- and pay the cost of the rails and their transport and properly and adequately equip the road, would take in the neighbourhood of $15,000 to $20,000 per mile. When my hon. friend speaks of $8,000 or $10,000 per mile, he is entirely astray in his calculations. Take the matter of equipment alone. If the country through which this road is to run is as fertile as represented, it will soon be filled up with producing settlers, and to carry their crops which will have to be carried by that railway will require large quantities of freight cars and locomotives. It is not a trifling matter to equip a railway with sufficient freight facilities to carry a traffic such as has been produced along the line of the Canadian Pacific Railway, and as will no doubt be produced along this line. And when you count the cost of the locomotives, freight cars and other equipment, I do not think that $5,000 or $6,000 per mile would be an unreasonable sum to expend in that way. Then when you come to realize on your bonds, what do you find ? I do not care how strong a company may be, or what may be its prospects, these bonds cannot be sold except at a considerable discount. Even bonds that bear the guarantee of the Manitoba government, when brought to the English market, have to be sold at a very substantial discount. I am not at liberty to say, but have been credibly informed what the extent of that discount is. If you undertakae to sell the bonds of a company with the brightest prospects in the world, in the English or any other market, not guaranteed by any government, and you have to submit to a
still larger discount. I do not believe that $25,000 of bonds will more that suffice to furnish the money necessary to construct and equip a road of this character, as it ought to be. Having that opinion, I did not think I should ask the committee to make any reduction of the bonding powers.
I would suggest that the following words be added to the last line of the fourth clause :	* Should not at any time exceed
$25,000 per mile on the government line of railway authorized to be constructed under this Act.' That will exclude the application to lines chartered under previous legislation and not chartered under this.

speechtext:
House in committee on Bill (No. 16) respecting the Manitoba and North-western Railway Company of Canada.-Mr. Douglas.
On section 1.

I wish to present here the resolution in amendment of which I gave notice the other evening, and which is to this effect-I wish to have inserted in this section the following, ' the company shall construct in the year 1902 thirty-five miles, and thirty-five miles in each and every year thereafter, including the year 190G.' I do not wish to take up time in discussing this matter for it was discussed fully in the Railway Committee. I brought this resolution up in the Railway Committee and they saw fit to disagree with me. Still I think it nothing but right to move it in the House. This company is in a different position from any other company that has come before the House asking for legislation. The Maui-, toba and North-western Railway Company was chartered in 1882, just 20 years ago. I have here copies of the statutes that were passed at that time and subsequently relating to this company. I find that in 1884, the company came back and received an extension of time. It was provided, however, that fifty miles of road should be built each and every year so long as the extension of time lasted. On the understanding that this would be done, a great many settlers went in on the proposed line. There was, in effect, a contract, with three parties to it- parliament, the promoters and the settlers. The settlers going in there figured that, under the arrangement made by parliament, the railway would reach them in a certain time. But the company did not build fifty miles a year-they did not built anything a year. At the end of the time to which their powers had been extended, they came and asked for another extension. Parliament in its wisdom, saw fit to give them a further extension, but inserted a clause in the Bill providing that the -company should _build twenty miles of road in each and every year. They came back again a few years after that, after they had built. I think, about 20 miles, and they got another extension of time for nine years, if I remember right, with the provision that they were to construct something like 20 miles a year. In an Act respecting the Manitoba and North-western Railway Company of Canada I find the following :

Section 2 of the Act passed in the 51st year of Her Majesty's reign, chapter 86, is hereby repealed, and the following substituted therefor :
The company shall complete during the calendar year 1890, the 17 miles of railway to the west of Saltcoats, in the territory of Assiniboia, partially constructed by it during the year 1889; and, in addition, the company shall complete not less than 20 miles of its railway, as described by the Acts relating to the company, on or before the 31st day of December, in the year 1892, and also during each calendar year thereafter, to the satisfaction of the Governor in Council ; otherwise the power granted to the company to extend its line of railway then completed shall be forfeited.
Now, they oarne back again in 1893 and got a further amendment to their charter which provided that they should build as much of the road as the Governor in Council should prescribe. That was something like nine years ago, and there has not been one foot of road built there from the time they got that charter to the present time. It is true, we are told this is not the same company. The Canadian Pacific Railway only got control of this road three or four years ago. That is true, but at the same time when the Caudian Pacific Railway bought this charter, as I believe they did, and when they took over this road, they took it over subject to these conditions. They knew the conditions and knew they ought to be fulfilled, and therefore when they took it over they had no right to assume they could get an extension of time, and I think they should have shown their bona fides by building twenty miles a year for each year, and as this was four years ago, there would have been eighty miles built now. Two years ago they came back to parliament and asked for an extension of time. The Bill came before the Railway Committee and was rejected, because they had not built any road at all. They came back this year without having constructed any road at all, and the committee lias given them an extension of time for another five years. They told the committee, and I believe they informed the gentleman who is handling the Bill, that they had let a contract for thirty-three miles. Well, my eyesight may be very bad, but I don't see anything about thirty-three miles in this Bill. I suppose the hon. gentleman that is handling the Bill knows more about it than I do, but there is not a word about it here. It may be on the back of it, but it is not in the Bill. I would like to be sure that we are going to get something done this year. Surely after this charter Was been in existence for twenty years it is not a fair proposition to give them five years more, saying they must commence in two years and complete in five. As I understand this Bill, they might build one mile this year, and then they would have five years more to complete that road; and if they did not do it they could come back and ask for another extension

of time. The argument has been used that there were no settlers along that line. 1 say that there are a great many settlers going in there; but if there was not one settler there, the fact that immigration is pouring into that country at the present time necessitates the opening up and developing of all the vast portions of the country. This railroad charter runs through one of the most fertile portions of the North-west Territories; it covers 230 miles of the finest lands in the Saskatchewan valley. We know that immigration has turned in the direction of the Saskatchewan valley, and I want to ask the House if it is fair to tie up that district for five years by giving a charter of this kind without something being in the charter to provide that a certain amount of work should be done within a given time. If you provide that thirty-five miles should be built each year the settlers will go in there on the strength of that provision, for they will know that the company is compelled to build a certain amount of road every year. If you do not do that, you are going 'to injure that district. They say that they have already promised to build thirty-three miles, and if they want to hold this charter for such a length of time, they should be prepared to construct thirty-five miles this year, and thirty-five miles each subsequent'year, including 1906.
Amendment negatived.
Bill reported, read the third time, and passed.

The matter was considered in the Railway Committee and we felt that we had very little data to go upon to enable us to form a judgment as to what would be the approximate cost of railway construction in that country. I
take it that this will be an electric tramway, and the plant for such a purpose, getting in the rails, wages, and all the expenses incidental to the constructing, operating and equipping of railway there, are out of all comparison with what they would be in eastern Canada. speechtext:
House in committee on Bill (No. 64) to incorporate the Cosmos Cotton Company.- Mr. Flint.
On section 7,
Why was the special provision stricken out of this Bill, that the majority of the corporation should be subjects of His Majesty.
This is frequently done in private Bills at the request of promoters, and the committee felt that it was very proper in this case.
I have not heard of it before.
It has been done, but I do not know why.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: Can the promoter of this Bill give one instance out of the numerous cases in which it has been done. My memory is that the practice of late years has been the very reverse.

I imagine that three out of every five private Bills have this clause. Based on broad ground, there is really no reason for the prohibition. At present such an enormous amount of foreign capital is invested in our enterprises that it is only proper that occasionally it should be provided that the directors need not be British subjects.
On section 8,
This clause gives the directors the power. I think that power should be in the stockholders.
The next clause provides for that.

The next clause requires the consent of the shareholders of

the other company to sell, but that has not the slightest application to section 8. Under section 8 one company can do this with the consent of the board of directors but they must have the consent of the shareholders of the other company.

The main object of this is to purchase the assets of the other company. This is quite an ordinary clause and is on the line of similar clauses in other private Bills. I really do not understand how any one can be injured in any way by this clause. The Bill was considered very carefully in the committee and no objection was taken to it.
When they come to purchase it requires the consent of every shareholder of the company purchased, but the purchasing company can do so without the consent of any shareholder.

Care is taken to safeguard the rights of the old company by requiring the consent of its shareholders to the sale, but if you were to pdt in any provision requiring the consent of the stockholders in the present company there might be difficulty.

It is not an unusual provision to enable the company to pay for property purchased by stock instead of money. Probably the objection of my hon. friend from Lanark is because we are enabling the purchase of a large property to be made without the consent of the shareholders.

I do not think that any difficulty need be anticipated on that account. The rights of the old company are safeguarded by requiring the consent of the shareholders, and the directors of the present company are simply authorized to issue paid up stock to the extent of the value of the property which they may purchase from the old company.

I do not wish to offer any objections for the purpose of delaying the Bill. If the hon. gentleman wants to consult any one with reference to it, we will consent to pass the Bill through the committee, but not allow the third reading until another day. In the meantime my hon. friend may look into the matter, and we can see whether any amendment be required on the third reading.
Bill reported.

House in Committee on Bill (No. 70) to incorporate the Ross Rifle Company.-Mr. Thompson.
On clause 8, subsection 2,

This section provides :
The aggregate amounts borrowed shall not at any time be greater than seventy-five per Hon. Mr. HAGGART.
cent of the actual paid up stock of the company, but this limitation shall not apply to commercial paper discounted by the company.
This is the first time I have seen such a clause in any private Bill. What does it mean ? There seems to be no limitations at all to the borrowing powers. Who is the member of the government in charge of private Bills ? This simply means that they can borrow as much as they like.
So can any company.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: I do not know that we ought to treat this question of the borrowing powers of companies in quite so frivolous a manner. Instances both here and in the old country will readily occur to the mind of every hon. gentleman showing the necessity of some restraint in the matter of borrowing powers of private companies. Some member of the government should be ready to answer questions put from this side of the House with regard to these masters. This question of incorporated companies should not be treated as if it had only a humourous side.

I understood the hon. exMinister of Railways (Mr. Haggart) to call attention to the borrowing powers given to the company under this clause. The committee unanimously agreed to the grant of these powers and we have not heard any reason advanced why the decision of the committee should be changed.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: If there is no limitation of the borrowing powers, what is the use of this clause ?
I think there are some limitations.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MARINE AND FISHERIES.

speechtext: In what respect ?

The clause, it seems to me, is not an unreasonable one. I understand the limitation to be a limitation upon their making a permanent loan on the strength of stock. This is a commercial company; it will be buying and selling, and it will have notes given it which, in the aggregate, may be more than the whole amount of the stock. It is provided that notes of that sort which are discounted with the bank, and which are held against goods supplied by them, shall not be included in the proportion of their borrowing, based upon their capital stock. It seems a reasonable clause, and the limitation seems a proper one.
I do not see the object of restricting it in one way only. I want to understand what the clause means, and I do not intend to enact it until I do understand.

I suppose the promoters would be satisfied to have it struck out.

This is the rule adopted by this parliament and in use for many years, in relation to joint stock companies. It has been applied in almost all Bills that have gone through. Personally, I never did agree with it, and do not agree with it now. But, until our general method of legislation in these matters is changed. speechtext: But this phrase ' commercial paper ' is a new phrase in legislation so far as I know. I do not know what the phrase means.

I think there is no ambiguity in the expression, for it is an expression in general use, and the meaning is well understood. There is a clear distinction in everybody's mind between a debenture or bond issued by an incorporated company and business paper of that company, and it is that distinction which this section, I apprehend, is meant to deal with. My hon. friend the senior member for Halifax (Mr. Borden) asks the principle upon which this limitation of 75 per cent was introduced. Almost every one of these companies' Acts, both English and Canadian, contains such a limitatiou as this. I think the precise limitation in England is just this 75 per cent; I know it is in many of the provinces. I think parliament desired that there should be a limitation placed upon the formal and more solemn-if you may so describe it-obligations issued by the company, which go into the hands of investors and are held for a term of years, and obligations that are made to-day and that mature in a few weeks or months, and which are closely watched and turned over and over. I think there is reason why the enduring obligations in the form of bonds issued by the company should not be unlimited, and if there is to be a limitation, it is not unreasonable, I think, that it should be in the neighbourhood of this 75 per cent. People that would be asked to invest in these bonds would have a guarantee by reason of this legislation that three-quarters only of the capital could be encumbered by the issue of these bonds.

What I said was that I thought it was slang so far as the statute is concerned. I think if he will consult modern works on the drafting of statutes he will find that any principle of that kind would be rather dangerous. I admit that the expression ' commercial paper ' is used among business people, and may be used in text books ; but when you wish to be exact as you should be in a statute, it is not a very proper expression to use.

It is a mere question of drafting. The first part of this section provides merely that the company shall borrow on its own security, that is to say, by way of mortgage, and the limitation is put of 75 per cent of the paid up capital stock of the company. With respect to their issue of commercial paper, to an unlimited amount, I think that is quite proper, because it is a well settled principle with us that commercial companies can issue negotiable paper to an unlimited extent. That is a mere matter to be settled as between themselves and their creditors. These words are used in this Bill to eliminate any doubt that might exist on the subject, and that is the only justification I can find for their occurrence here.

The limitation here is not to the extent or 75 per cent of the value of the property mortgaged, but it is a limitation to 75 per cent of the paid up capital of the stock, or something of that kind. That, in the opinion of this House, the system of training citizens of Canada for the positions of officers in the active militia should be such aa would furnish the greatest number of properly qualified persons in each regimental district necessarily required, upon a war basis, at the least possible cost consistent with efficiency ; and that all needless hindrances, customs and expense in the way of any and every citizen obtaining such military education should be removed.	.
He said : In presenting this motion to the House I am merely carrying out the policy that I have for the last ten or twelve years advocated in this House, namely:	That
the cost of training the officers in Canada should be reduced to a minimum, consistent with due efficiency being maintained. It is well known to every one connected with our militia force that the trained officers are not at all numerous enough in that force at present. There is in fact a dearth of officers, and it is no secret that in fitting out the few regiments we sent to South Africa, there has been considerable trouble in getting properly qualified and trained officers to accept these commands. It was my intention to bring this matter up in its present form last year, but I deferred it in the hope that the unfortunate and prolonged war in South Africa might be brought to a close. In view of the undoubted approach of peace now, I feel justified in laying before the House and the country my views on this question. The subject is not at all new to me. In England as well as in Canada I have noticed a deficiency in qualified officers to command the men who have voluteered to serve. I have visited on various occasions military centres in Canada and in Great Britain, and I found that a spirit had grown up and had been perpetuated among the regular officers of the Imperial service and of the permament corps-a spirit of, what they themselves call superciliousness ; a spirit which must bode ill to any nation perpetuating it. The officer who is merely an officer for the sake of the position it may confer on him ; the officer who does not give his whole heart and his whole soul to the cause he is engaged in cannot by any possibility be a proper officer to lead men on active service. The Montreal ' Gazette ' of to-day, commenting on a very carefully prepared article by the American Col. Charles W. Larned in the ' International Monthly,' says :
It is not, however, from the recognition of the long acknowledged merits of our soldiers, but from the admitted shortcomings of those who command them that the profitable lessons of recent warfare are to be drawn. Col. Larned finds the British officer of to-day pretty much what his predecessor was in the days of Frederic the Great-' without knowledge of war. without fear of death.'

Tliis, as we all know, is an extract from Thomas Carlyle. I do not for a moment pretend to say that the officers of the Canadian permanent corps and the British regular army are not In every sense of the word brave men, but I say that they are not thoroughly trained to command in the face of the modern conditions of war. That there is need of reform is admitted on every hand, and my only reason for taking the stand I do is to insist, so far as it lies in my power, that the required reform should be carried out, not only in our colonial system but in the Imperial system as well, because it cannot be too well understood that Canada is a part of the empire and purposes remaining so. We all know, however, that once war is over, things have a strong tendency to fall back into the old groove, and I have no doubt that unless the sturdy, intelligent commercial classes of England and the empire take this matter up, in a year or two you will find the Piccadilly ring in full sway again, and the zeal for reform completely set at naught, and it is in order to do what little I can to bring about reform and prevent a relapse into our old staid condition of apathy that I take this opportunity of placing myself on record.
In the olden time-and not so very many years ago after all-the weapon used by the British was a muzzle loader, with a range of from 250 to 300 yards. Frontal attacks were then possible, and in such attacks the stern, unflinching bravery of the British soldier was unexcelled. As soon as the enemy had discharged one volley and before they could reload, the British troops were into them with the bayonet, and the British bayonet invariably carried the day. Times, however, have since then changed. In the Crimean war many of the British regiments were armed with the Minnie rifle, which had a range possibly 150 to 200 yards longer. This struck terror into the hearts of the Russians and largely assisted in the demoralization of that force by greatly inferior numbers of British troops. In the American war, the Springfield rifle was chiefly used, but the Americans also purchased a large number of the Enfield muzzle loaders. In fact, very few, if any, breech loaders were then in use. Now, take any record you choose of that war, take the record of the proprietor of the Ottawa ' Free Press,' Mr. Chas. Mitchell, who fought gallantly through it, take the record of any historian and you will find that they all bear out this statement, that with the muzzle loading rifles, having a range of from 305 to 400 yards, a frontal attack is out of the question, and it is absolutely impossible to capture any position by such tactics. In the Egyptian campaign, we find the same conclusion borne out. And I do not know that I can do better than quote from an unbounded authority, Henderson's History of the American Civil War, to show the effect of the old muzzle loading rifles on troops advancing in frontal attack.
Mr. HUGHES 'Victoria).
And we must not forget that although in those days, a man could not load and fire more than two shots while the enemy was advancing against him, yet even then it was absolutely impossible for a frontal attack to succeed. Here is Mr. Henderson's description of how persistently the Northern troops endeavoured to drive the Southerners from their entrenchments, and how, though the Northerners were in overwhelming numbers, their attacks were repulsed :
Morell's attack was directed against Jackson's right. In the centre of the Federal line a mounted officer, whose gallant bearing lived long in the memories in the Stonewall division, rode out in front of the column, and, drawing his sabre, led the advance over the rolling grass-land. The Confederate batteries, with a terrible cross-fire, swept the Northern ranks from end to end. The volleys of the infantry, lying behind their parapet, struck them full in face. But the horse and its rider lived through it all. The men followed close, charging swiftly up the slope, and then the leader, putting his horse straight at the embankment, stood for a moment on the top. The daring feat was seen by the whole Confederate line, and a yell went up from the men along the railroad, ' Don't kill him 1 don't kill him 1 ' But while the cry went up horse and rider fell in one limp mass across the earthwork, and the gallant Northerner was dragged under shelter by his generous foes.
With such men as this to show the way what soldiers would be backward V .As the Russians followed Skobeleff's grey up the Moody slopes of Plevna, so the Federals followed the bright chestnut of this unknown hero, and not till the colours waved within thirty paces of the parapet did the charge falter. But, despite the supports that came thronging up, Jackson's soldiers, covered by the earthwork, opposed a resistance which no mere frontal attack could break. Three times, as the lines in rear merged with the first, the Federal officers brought their men forward to the assault, and three times they were hurled back, leaving hundreds of their number dead and wounded on the blood-soaked turf. One regiment of the Stonewall division, posted in a copse beyond the railroad, was driven in, but others, when cartridges failed them, had recourse, like the Guards at Inkerman, to the stones which lay along the railway bed; and with these strange weapons, backed up by the bayonets, more than one desperate effort was repulsed. In arresting Garnet after Kernstown, because when his ammunition was exhausted he had abandoned his position, Jackson had lost a good general, but he had taught his soldiers a useful lesson. So long as the cold steel was left to them, and their flanks were safe, they knew that their indomitable leader expected them to hold their ground, and right gallantly they responded. For over thirty minutes the battle raged along the front of the closest range. Opposite a deep cutting the colours of a Federal regiment, for nearly half an hour, rose and fell, as bearer after bearer was shot down within ten yards of the muzzles of the Confederate rifles, and after the fight a hundred dead Northerners were found where the flag had been so gallantly upheld.
I might refer to another battle, the battle of Sharpesburg, where out of 19,400 South-

era troops, 5,754 were placed out of action in the short space of three hours, while making a frontal attack in the face of muzzle loading rifles.
In the present day our rifles have a range five times as great as those with which Jackson's troops faced the Northerners at the battle of Bull's Run. But no account seems to have been taken of the changed conditions by our British oflflcers. In the face of this improvement in weapons, despite the great advantage of smokeless powder and the consequent impossibility almost of ascertaining exactly the enemy's position, we have seen in Africa frontal attack after frontal attack made by British troops. We have seen brave men storming the heights of Belmont-an acclivity steeper than the banks of the Ottawa river here- when they could have walked around the position, thrown up their entrenchments, and rested on the plains smoking their pipes, waiting for Cronje to be starved into surrender for want of food and water. We saw our troops advance on the Modder river in like manner. We saw them following the same tactics at Magersfontein, Oolenso, Stormberg, and Graspan. To this blundering system we can attribute a series of disasters. British troops, whose courage no man dare question, advanced fearlessly in the face of rifles, with a range at least five times as great as those used in the American war, and that was called generalship. It is time we should realize that the strategy and tactics of the old days are worse than ineffective at present. Greater attention must be paid to scouting. Formerly it would have been safe to march across country, with a patrol 400 yards distant on each side, because that was the range of the enemy's rifle. But to do so to-day would simply make one food for powder for an enemy occupying positions a mile distant on either side. But our British officer seems unable to recognize the changed conditions. As Carlyle says of them : He knows how to die, but not how to lead. With a rifle having a range of 3,000 yards, the old formation is absolutely impracticable. To face a line to-day, with each man distant fifty yards, is a much more dangerous performance than it would have been, with the old style of rifle to have placed the men only a yard distant. But this evidently has not dawned on many of the officers in South Africa at present, and you have distinguished generals placing their men almost in close formation, waiting for the Boers to round them up. and then you have another of these unfortunate surrenders that have saddened the hearts of so many in the empire. I have an extract here from a western Ontario paper, and it sums the matter up in very terse form :
In hand-to-hand fights the British have no equal. In brain-to-brain contests they appear to be seriously handicapped. Strategy counts in modern warfare. Our British officers do not
appear to be strategists. We must honestly confess that from what we have seen of the Englishman ' just out ' from England we have not been very favourably impressed with his tact or bis abilities. We are of the opinion that the British army needs a thorough re-organization, based on promotion by merit and not birth. When that system is introduced in the army we may then expect to see capable and efficient service on the part of the British military forces.
I have pointed out, incidentally, that no fault can possibly be found with the British soldier. In the war in South Africa he has been the marvel of the world for the bravery, endurance and heroism he has shown. The British soldier has never complained, he has done his duty on any and every occasion, and wherever he has been led he has followed. Nor can any fault be found with the bravery of the British officers I am free to say the British officer is a well-meaning fellow, as a rule, a very genial fellow. Still, the great weakness of the British army is the training of the British officers. No army hereafter can expect to have an officer for every half . company and have his men within reach of his voice, or to have a sergeant for every section. Training in the future must be in the direction of fitting every individual to control himself, subject to an elastic discipline covering the whole force. And, in this very excellent article by Col. Tamed to which I have already referred, it is pointed out that the logic of events has necessitated a further reduction, and, in the future, the fighting unit will be the individual soldier. With that conclusion any one who has studied the modern conditions will agree-that the object of the training must be to make each individual command and control himself, subject, as I have said, to an elastic discipline covering the whole body.
In discussing a question of this kind one is very liable to be misunderstood. My good and intelligent friend the Minister of Militia and Defence (Hon. Mr. Borden), entirely misunderstood the tenor of my remarks in a recent discussion. And when an intelligent man and one accustomed to the discussion of these things, such as my good friend the minister is, will take one up wrongly-yet I thought I spoke very clear English-how much more easily may one be misunderstood by the uninitiated in the! country, particularly when his remarks go before them in partial form. However, I trust that on this occasion there will be no misunderstanding. No one, I trust, will run away with the notion, for instance, that I am, in any sense, a pro-Boer. At the same time I want to say that the Boer individually is a splendid fellow. As I reminded the House a year ago. the Boer is descended from two grand races, the Dutch and Huguenots of France, and finer men individually, considering the opportunities they have had, it would be hard to find. And when they have received the benefit of British civilization and British institutions, when they have

learned to be free men in the true sense of the term, I am satisfied that Britain will find very few of her colonists more progressive and more loyal than these Boers in South Africa. I trust that the day is not far distant when this result will be attained. While a man may respect an opponent he fights with, yet it is his duty to take every honourable advantage of him, that is, it is his duty to defeat him as speedily as possible and bring the war to a close. The greatest friend of the Boer I maintain has not been the Hollander, it has not been even the Irish American. And on that point I may say that those on the British side in South Africa have the highest admiration and respect for the gallant soldiers of the Irish race who fought so nobly and so well on the side of Britain in that war. And they had a complete respect for any soldier fighting against them who stood up and gave them a severe fight. But they have nothing but supreme contempt for the so-called Irish brigade led by Col. Burke, who ran whenever a shot was fired against them. The Germans were supposed to be friendly to the Boers. But that is a mistake, because the people of German birth in Africa, whether living among the Boers or among the British were almost unanimously proBritish. One would naturally expect the sympathy of these people to go with the Boers because of their smaller numbers in this war. But, Sir, the greatest friend of the Boers to my mind is the badly trained British officer. We all know that Britain has never been loved by foreign nations. Rivalry in trade, in progress, in civilization and liberty have made Britain more or less detested by other powers, yet she was always feared by other nations because of her supposed prowess in war. But I very much fear that to-day, owing to the number of failures in the field in South Africa, there is less of that tendency to respect Britain through fear than there formerly was. How ever, with proper reform in the army, with better training for her officers, she will be able to keep the proud position she has held in the respect of other nations. Here let me quote further from our American friend Col. Larned some words that will show the solidity of Britain's power :
No other power on earth could have placed an equipped army of 200,000 on another continent 10,000 miles away.
And he goes on :
And for that matter what warrior on the globe can show a 1 ke record of endurance ana glory in foreign climes as the British Grenadier who, fi'om equator to pole, has marched and bled and conquered, founded empires, overthrown despotisms and made ready the ground for an imposing structure of equity, order, sound finance and peace.
These are the opinions of an American critic, and I heartily endorse them. And when the British army is properly trained, that is when the officers of the British army are Mr. HUGHES (Victoria).
properly trained, I am satisfied that the one weakness in that great body will have been remedied. There is a delusion harboured by many that an officer must be one of the aristocracy, that an aristocratic army is necessary to the up-building of a limited monarchy. People in this country will hardly have any such opinion. We have seen the sons of tailors, shoemakers and farmers rise to the proud position of Lord High Chancellor of Great Britain. We have seen these sons of the same class of men rise to the highest places in the commerce of the nation, and also in the church. I fail, then, to see why the sons of these same men, given the proper opportunity should not rise to similar positions in the army. As Mr. Hales, the very able correspondent of the Australian paper pointed out in an article which I see in the ' Montreal Star ' of January 18th, 1902.
I contend that there is nothing, or there should be nothing in a properly constituted army, to cause a man to lose caste by joining as a ranker. Put a gentleman and a farm labourer side by side in the ranks to-morrow, and the gentleman, if he is made of the proper material, ought to distance his opponent in every kind of legitimate competition. He starts the contest with all the advantages that an excellent education carry, he has knowledge of many things which must help him if he is an earnest soldier, knowledge which the farm labourer fcas had no chance of obtaining. If, with such a handicap as that, he cannot win his way above the heads of his fellows, win it fairly like a man, it must be because he is lacking in qualities which he should possess, and if he lacks those qualities the army is no place for him, because the Imperial army of the future must not be a hothouse for exotics. I would make no distinction. If the King's son desired to wear a soldier's uniform, he should first of all wear the humble dress of one of his royal father's privates. Why should he not. ? Is it a badge of disgrace, a mark of dishonour ? Have not thousands of well-bred men all over the empire donned the private's uniform, and fought in it during the present war, and are they any worse for having done so ? Have they contracted any moral leprosy. Have they forfeited the right to call themselves gentlemen V Personally I think not ; a gentleman can be a gentleman in a lance-corporal's uniform _juite as surely as in a Field Marshal's if he is made of the correct material ; if not, then why all this talk of native superiority ? Is it the Bond Street tailor who makes the gentleman and the East end sweater who makes the ' Tommy 7 ' I don't believe it, I won't believe it.
These are the words of Mr. Hales, the very able correspondent from Australia, who lias made himself a name throughout the British Empire in his criticisms of the Imperial army. Then we hear the statement made that the men prefer fighting under officers of the aristocratic class. I fail to see that that is the case either, and I maintain that tile history of the British Empire shows-that the men who fight under officers of their own class fight as bravely and as willingly as the men of any other corps in the-

service, and the same is time of Canadians. However, I do not object to the, officers of the British Empire being taken from the aristocratic class. By all means give them every opportunity; but first of all let it be required of them, as Mr. Hales says, that they should be equal in every respect, and superior in many respects, to any other type of men that they may seek to discipline. Let them be trained for the position of leading men, so that when they are placed in control of the lives of their fellow citizens they will not make the fatal blunders that have too often been made in the present unfortunate war in South Africa. A very eminent Dutch Reformed minister in South Africa, in writing to Mr. D. J. Malan, a pro-Boer of Wellington, Cape Colony, says :
I believe those who keep this miserable struggle going are the pro-Boers of England, and the merciless Kruger clique on the continent of which Paul Kruger is the head. They have not sent their people (women and children) one cent as far as I know ; while the British nation is spending thousands upon us.
This is an extract from an open letter of this very prominent Dutch Reformed minister to a pro-Boer living in Cape Colony. Now, the British pro-Boer is a man who should have some respect for his own mother, he should love his empire, he should back his own people against the enemy, come from what source they may. He knows, if he knows anything, that the British never fought in a more righteous war in the whole history of the empire; yet the British pro-Boer, for the object of gaining some political point, or to uphold some fad, and yet realizing the tolerance of i Jreat Britain, never misses an opportunity of helping the Boers. This man, Sir, I maintain is the most despicable of creatures,, and as this clergyman rightly says, is no doubt the cause of the war being prolonged.
