Mr. Speaker, the British pro-Boer has assisted the Boers in demanding a peace, which, in the opinion of the best men of the empire is not honourable. He has helped the Boers by condemning the humane action of the British in caring for the women and children of the Boer forces in South Africa. This is, 1 think, the first instance in the history of warfare where a nation which has conquered another has taken care of the women and children and thus relieved the enemy of one of the greatest burdens that any people could possibly have placed upon their shoulders. In this respect I have to point out that we find no commiseration from these British pro-Boers for the thous-85
ands and tens of thousands of loyalist women and children who have, since the month of October, 1899, been refugees, who have been encamped at various parts in the loyal districts in South Africa, refugees from the districts included in the war area of Johannisburg, Pretoria, Bloemfontein, Kimberley, north of Kimberley and the various centres where these people had, in thousands, to seek refuge in the concentration camps. You find no sympathy for these women and children on the part of these British pro-Boers. Yet, when you bring Boer women and children into one of your concentration camps you do something that shocks all these pro-Boers. In that way they have encouraged the Boers in the field and have assisted them in continuing the war. But, the British pro-Boer has also helped the Boers in arms by censuring the men to whom the British Empire owes so much in this matter-Mr.	Chamberlain,
Lord Milner, Lord Salisbury and Mr. Balfour. These men have been unstintingly condemned by the British pro-Boers. Money in thousands, I believe, has been expended by the Boer agencies throughout the world to create an adverse opinion to these men. But, on the other hand, it has assisted in creating a kindly sympathy' for them in South Africa and other British colonies. By these actions I claim the British pro-Boer has been disloyal to his country because he has encouraged the Boers to continue in the war. He has also been disloyal by giving assistance to the enemy, by encouraging the demand on the part of the Boers that in consideration of laying down their arms they should have certain concessions granted to them in the way of independence or semi-independence. This, I am satisfied, would be regarded with the greatest antagonism by all loyalists throughout the empire. The Boers from the outset have known the terms upon which they could obtain conditions should they surrender. 1 am not going to speak of any negotiations that may have taken place at one time or another during the war for a settlement honourable to both parties that might have been reached, but any settlement granting the Boers independence, or semi-independence, free from British supremacy, free from the British flag, could not be tolerated by the British Empire or by Great Britain as a unit. This district, as I have previously pointed out to this House, is absolutely necessary to be held for Great Britain as underlying the integrity and peace of South Africa. Great Britain must have her naval stations and coaling stations at the Gape. Therefore, I claim that those who have been instrumental in| encouraging the Boers in the field have been disloyal and are so still. The British pro-Boer also helps the Boer by holding out a helping hand of encouragement to those pro-Boer emissaries who have been roaming Europe and -the United States. Then, he has helped the Boers in the field by slandering



one of the grandest of men. I refer to Mr. Thomas Atkins. The British soldier has been unstintingly slandered in this war. Foreign nations have not hesitated to charge him with all kinds of atrocities. I venture to say that not one case of outrage or atrocity from the beginning to the end of the war has been proven against the British soldier. On every occasion, so far as any definite record can show, the British soldier has conducted himself towards women and children with the same kindness that always characterizes the British soldier. He treats the enemy just as he would treat a fallen friend; so that, there is nothing in that charge. I can give instances-in fact I have given instances-where attempts were made to assert that unkindness and harsher methods than were necessary had been resorted to by the British soldiers towards these people, but X am satisfied that these assertions find no echo in the hearts of any loyal persons or of any persons who understand the conditions of South Africa. The Boers have also been helped in the field by those who have been ever apologising for Boer outrages. I do not say that the Boers have been outrageous towards the loyalist women. I am proud to say they also have shown that magnanimity of spirit that characterizes the races from which they sprung and, from which the British soldier has sprung, but that they have been tricky, cowardly and brutal in the manner in which they have entrapped the British soldier no one can deny. They have again and again shown the white flag on one part of the field in order to decoy the British soldiers while they have had, on another part of the field, a force of men concealed ready to shoot down the British soldiers like so many rabbits. This occurred more frequently early in the war than during recent times. They have again and again held up their hands in token of surrender and as soon as the British would advance they would pick up their rifles, and shoot them down. They have been allowed through the kindness of heart of the British generals to retire to their 'farms when they saw the British advance and, taking up their rifles, which had been buried, they have waylaid and captured British convoys. When they would be waited upon by a British officer they would place their hands to their hearts, look the British officer in the face and say :	We
did hear some firing last night and they went away over there. I could give instancy after instance of this sort of thing. These British pro-Boers always have very great sympathy for that type of fellow. It is not my intention, in my criticism to build up that sort of man. My desire is to strengthen the bonds of the British Empire and the British army which has been weakened by the inferior training of the British officer. It is also my desire to make it clear that no one class in the empire is absolutely necessary to the building up of Mr. HUGHES (Victoria).
the empire, that no one class has a monopoly of loyalty to this country. To pass through Britain and to listen to many of these gentlemen who constitute a large number of the army officers, one would imagine that the English army officer was himself the great bulwark of the British Empire and that he had a monopoly of loyalty. 1 wish it to be understood that the inhabitants of the farms in the back parts of Canada, of the remote stations in Australia, in New Zealand and in South Africa, the rank and file, have as high an appreciation of their duty to the British Empire and as great an affection for the old land as the most highly titled aristocrat in the empire, and his good will and assistance are just as necessary for maintaining the supremacy of the empire as are those of any one on the other side of the water. In speaking of the campaign in South Africa, I may be permitted to point out that the departments-I trust the hon. Minister of Militia and Defence'will make a note of this even if I do not go into that point in detail, and specify clearly as I can the particulars-that were brought in contact with the British business heart have been successful. The mobilizing of the troops, the merchant stations, the transport of troops, the merchant ships engaged in handling the freight, the supplies, the munitions of Avar, the transport of these commodities to the seat of war, by that magnificent Cape government system of railways-all those services have been a success. I hesitate to mention the name of any one officer above that of another who deserves credit, but I will mention the name of Mr. Price the assistant superintendent of the Cape system of railways. All these departments connected with transportation, organization, rations, equipment, supplies, the management of trains and of ships, all of these departments which came into immediate contact with the civil, commercial and business communities, hav^e been an entire success and only one department, the combatant department, has been found a failure. Do not misunderstand me, Sir, there have been found in the combatant department, in spite of the inferior system of training, men Avho have succeeded beyond all measure, men whose names will go down in history as having shed lustre on the British arms and men who invariably brought honour to her cause. In spite of the lack of training their innate adaptability has found A'ent and they have succeeded in retaining the prestige of Britain-names such as White, the hero of Ladysmith, French, whom I consider to be after all the most modern soldier, General Alderson, Lord Kitchener, Knox, Kelly-Kenny, Lord Roberts, Settle, Hunter, the Hamiltons, Brabant, Scobell, Smith-Dorrien, Dundonald, Pole-Carew, Rimington and some others. These men proved -that, despite the dwarfing system of Great Britain, the greatness of the names which they bear have sur-

vived and that they have made themselves an absolute necessity to the success of the British arms.
I did purpose speaking in detail in reference to the treatment of the colonial officers by the Imperial officer in Africa, and when I refer to Africa I would extend my remarks to include the treatment of the militia officer in Canada and the militia officer in the old country, by the Imperial officer generally. No one doubts that there is a very bitter feeling between the colonial officers in Africa to-day, and the Imperial officer. That goes without saying. It is dwelt on in every newspaper. The Toronto ' Telegram ' lias a long article on the subject from which I read the following extract :
The complaints which come from South Africa over the English officers' treatment of the colonial officers may be explained partially by misunderstanding and partially by the narrow intelligence of the worst sort of English officer. The cause of the trouble is deeper than the contempt of the Englishmen for the colonials. The real trouble is the arrogant intolerance which marks the attitude of the professional soldier tcward the amateur soldier.
This arrogance is a folly not peculiar to English officers. Hundreds of English officers are free from such a feeling, and Canada's permanent force has bred in many of Its officers as fine a line of contempt for the volunteer officer as any Aldershot Englishman can display.
It is not a question of old countryman and colonial. It is simply a question of brains or no trains.
The Toronto ' Globe ' has also commented on this matter, and the ' Mail ' published an article of considerable length in reference to it. These officers of the permanent corps have a kind of close corporation among themselves, and they fear that if any extension is encouraged in the militia it will threaten the permanency and the exclusiveness of their system. I have, 1 think, successfully explained to a number of those gentlemen that the result of the establishment of a large militia force along proper lines in the old country as well as in Canada, would be to immensely strengthen the hands of these officers, if these officers are what they should be, and if they are not, then they should be relegated to other walks of life where they will not he as so many pensioners on the pay sheet of the nation. I may point out that in the early part of the war, no colonial officer, no matter how high his rank or how great his experience, was given any post of command. At Belmont; at Gras Pan; at Modder river; at Maggersfontein; at Stormberg, there were no colonials, and there were but a few at Colenso, under Lord Dundonald. None of these colonial officers held commands and in many cases British officers of lower rank were placed over them. I trust that the Minister of Militia will take note of this. We have in Africa to-day, colonials who should be perfectly qualified to command these corps, and to command in action If 851
necessary; but yet, there is not one Canadian in Africa who has ever commanded a corps independently in an engagement. Col. Otter of the first contingent was never entrusted with a command. He planned the Sunnyside expedition, furnished all the data in connection with it, but when it came to carrying out the plan, an officer junior to him-a very good officer indeed, and 1 have nothing to say against him-but an officer the junior of Col. Otter was sent to command the expedition, and Col. Otter remained at the base to play second fiddle. In the advance on Stormberg, that memorable night when General Gatacre met with disaster; a colonial officer who had been born and brought up in the region and knew its dangers, ventured to caution General Gatacre upon the blunder he was about to make, but he got his dismissal there and then. That colonial officer showed me the note from General Gatacre dismissing him from his command, because, knowing the region, he dared to point out to the General that he was taking a wrong route and that danger lurked ahead. Where ever you go in South Africa you will find that no colonial officer got any prominence or any command in the field. If the British officer is at all competent, the colonial officer is, by hook or crook, put under him. The premier of New Zealand has taken a very pronounced stand upon this matter, and I trust that our Minister of Militia will look into it. Mark you, I have not changed one whit in my belief that it is Canada's duty under proper conditions to continue to assist Britain for the protection of the empire at large, but in all such matters as this Canada should see to it that her officers are properly commissioned and entrusted with proper commands in the field.
I now come to the discussion of the Canadian as well as the Imperial permanent forces. We are told that any departure from the present system would be the breaking up of discipline. I dare say many hon. gentlemen in this House have visited the barracks of a permanent corps, and have seen some illustration of what they call discipline. Let us take for example how our young fellows attend these institutions, and I have a case in mind now which will illustrate what their idea of discipline is. Three sons of a family go to the city of Toronto; one enters as a' private in one of the schools; one happens to be an officer, and the youngest attends the Toronto university. The private enters the school through a doorway guarded by a man with fixed bayonet; he is taken to the barrack room where he is made to sleep with a lot of fellows possibly congenial spirits and possibly not. His food and his clothing and his bedding are of the commonest kind. I find no fault with that, for if a fellow is going to be a soldier he should take soldiers fare. The other brother passes into the officers quarters; he has no fixed time to regulate him; he has not to turn his light

out and go to bed at a certain hour. If the young private wants to study he has to do so in a room where there are a great many others, but when the officer wishes to study he can retire to his room, although there is always more or less entertainment provided for him. The private must have his light out at a certain hour of the night the same as a penitentiary bird. Now take the lot of the young man attending the university. >
He lives where he wishes; he is a free man. The one is a young fellow with a desire to serve his country; the other is training to be a business man, but the latter is free and the other is not. I venture to say that the so-called discipline to which the private is subjected, unmans him and unfits him to as great an extent as the independent surroundings of the other tends to make him a good, and self-reliant citizen. There are 6,000 young men studying at the universities in Toronto, and I venture to say that they are better men in the end than if they were subjected to this so-called discipline of the military school. In the military school they call the rule and restrictions of prison life, discipline. Why, under the present ticket of leave system, the prisoners in Kingston penitentiary are not far removed from the discipline which the soldiers are subjected to in one of our permanent corps. The serfdom of the dark ages, they call discipline; the slavery of the old time and the subjection of the blacks, they call it discipline. The repressing of the human mind and of the human soul; they term discipline. The plebeian spirit which a great many endeavour to infuse into the people, (which we find unfortunately in the ignorant and the broken spirited poor) and the fawning of flunkies, that is what these gentlemen term discipline. They do not understand that anything which tends to unman a man, to humble and to humiliate him and to degrade him, is the reverse of discipline. Discipline to them is repression and not freedom. Discipline to them is fear and debasement, and not the ennobling or the uplifting of our fellow man. Their so-called system is control from without, without any self-control or control from within. One English paper speaking of the war says :
Battles cannot be won without systematic training in the science of war. But what is the science of war ? The Boers have made successful war without caring a fig for the so-called science that Europe has been slavishly and systematically following for generations.
I maintain that history proves that where an equal number of free men have met an equal number of these so-called soldiers of rigid discipline similarly armed, victory has invariably rested with the free men. Read history from the earliest days to the present, and you will find that wherever regular armies have met irregular armies equally equipped, the regular armies have always suffered defeat. Long before this Boer war began, I pointed out to the general
Mr. HUGHES fVictoria).
officer commanding in Canada, that unless the British tactics in the coming war were changed, disaster sure and dire would befall the British arms as it did in the African war of 1881.
The British system has the result of converting freemen into serfs or slaves, or men whose liberty is oppressed by so-called discipline. The discipline of these gentlemen belongs to the days when tyrants and divine right rulers held sway, which fortunately have gone by. It belongs to the period when manhood was considered a crime, when freedom and liberty were unknown, and human hearts ground down beneath oppression and repression. That form of discipline should long since have vanished from liberty-loving, self-governing communities. It survives only in prisons and similar institutions in the Dominion of Canada to-day, in the permanent corps, and in the British regular army. Let me give an illustration. Here are two young fellows in the city of Toronto. One is a university student, and the other is a private attending the school in order to gain his certificate. They both go to the theatre, and the one comes home just as sober as the other. The student sits up a good part of the night and studies and gets up and goes to lecture in the morning and nothing is said to him. But the other, because he arrived in barracks a few minutes late, is locked up in the guard room all night, brought before some officer in the morning, and treated with greater indignity than if he had robbed a bank. He is probably confined in barracks for a certain number of days. I remember in the old days, when our annual camps were surrounded by fixed bayonets, the young fellows used to break out at night on purpose just to start the guards and give them a run. I have often done it myself when a private, and when any of the boys got caught, they simply put it down to their bad luck. But there was always more disorder in the camp in those days, when surrounded by fixed bayonets, than in the camps we have had this last couple of years, where there are no guards except where the stores are kept. That goes to show simply that trained men can control themselves and that self-control is the highest form of existence.
A destructive critic, I may say, I regard as a nuisance, and I do not intend to put myself In that category. If I point out the failures in the system, I am always prepared to suggest a substitute. I have shown that I would give the greatest freedom to the young men in the permanent corps as well as to the young men attending the schools. To-day. when we want an officer to attend the military schools, what do we do ? We send in an application for such an pfflcer to attend a course at the permanent schools at a certain time. Let me give an instance that came within my own experience last year, to show how this system

works. A young officer was anxious to attend the school, but his business engagements prevented his doing so at any other time than the beginning of the year. He sent in his application to be allowed to attend at that period, but a few weeks later he got an order to attend the 1st of November-a thing which it was absolutely impossible for him to do. He therefore gave up all idea of attending at all. Two days, however, before the 1st of January, an order came for him to go to the school, but of course not having anticipated this, he had made other arrangements, so that it was absolutely impossible for him to comply with the order. Thus he lost his opportunity. I would pursue a different plan. Instead of educating a limited number of men herded up together in a barracks, subjected to the indignity of so-called discipline-the discipline of prison repression-I would allow these young men to board in and around the city. They would then report for drill at certain hours, and go through all the routine in barracks necessary for a soldier to learn. And let me tell you. Sir, that two-tliirds of the so-called training, practiced in the schools, is absolute nonsense. As described by a writer in the ' Free Press ' of Saturday last-a gentleman whose name I happen to know, and who is an officer occupying a very distinguished position-it is ' absolute rot.' 1 would have these young men board outside and report themselves each day. I would not have them there as soldiers, but as cadets, wearing a separate uniform from the regulars. They would have to report at certain hours, which in itself is great discipline, as they have to get up in the early morning and sometimes walk miles for the purpose of attending drill. .1 would have them go through their drill and routine, item by item, and let them fill position after position. I would even have them in the lecture room instructing their juniors and doing the same work in the field. In other words, I would have our permanent corps officers occupy a much more dignified position. Instead of storming around the barrack yard and bullying a few poor cadets, I would have them occupy rather the positions of lecturers or professors in a college, and all this routine of scrubbing floors and making up beds, which it is of no earthly use for men to learn, I would do away with altogether, and let these recruits attend the schools as students, learn everything they could, and then go home. How is it now ? We have a course amounting to usually three months for the privates and non-coms ; then we have a course for subalterns of another three months ; then there is another course for captains and field officers' certificates, and Commanding officers' certificates, and musketry instruction certificates. A man has to loaf around Ottawa five or six weeks in order to get a musketry instruction certificate, which any one of ordinary intelligence, and who has ever handled a rifle, could pick up in a day or two. Then there is the signalling course. But not one of these things is done systematically. A bit is done here and another bit there. The equitation course, the musketry course, the signalling course, the maxim gun course-all these various courses are scattered about, and instead of a young man being able to take the whole thing and go through it all in about fifteen straight months, he has to take them at intervals and breaks up three or four years in the work. All this instruction should be centralized. Let us have a school at Toronto, another at Ottawa, and so on, but have everything centralized in the one school. And I would have the young cadet enter at sixteen years of age or even younger. General Wolfe was an adjutant of his regiment, and a very good soldier, when sixteen years old. Nearly one-third of the men who stormed the heights at Alma were under twenty years of age. Nearly one-third of the men who stood in Wellington's veteran squares at Waterloo, were under twenty years of age, and had been enlisted less than six weeks. What we require is officers, and 1 would turn them out in unlimited numbers. And when they return to their homes you can always call on them again as part of the reserve. By paving these young officers trained, you would have a large number of men on whom you could call at a moment's notice, fit to command your troops and trained in the best way possible. I would have discipline from within- the unit controlling himself, rather than hampered and hedged in by these so-called disciplinary rules of the school. I cannot do better than quote from this very able article in Saturday's Daily ' Free Press.' I happen to know the pen of the writer as well as the young officer who edits the column in that paper. The writer, speaking of an article in the 'Canadian Military Gazette,' says :
These facts hold good under prevailing conditions. If the schools wore as efficient as they should be, a provisional school would not be the most suitable and would not give better results, but as things exist to-day there is no doubt but the advantages are in favour of local training.
Some time ago, I took the liberty of making a slight criticism on the schools, which excited some attention, and I was charged by the minister with wishing to abolish the schools entirely. Far from it. Ever since I have been in the House-some twelve sessions-I have brought this matter up and endeavoured to bring about reforms. And I am proud to say that the reforms I advocated many years ago, have, many of them, been carried out by this and previous administrations. What I ask is reform of the schools and not their abolition. The , writer in the ' Free Press ' goes on to say :

This is an exact statement of the facts and the only difference is that in both cases it is drill, drill, useless drill-one on twenty yards square of gravel, and the other on a boarded drill hall floor and the lectures and everything else are practically the same. In spite of the fact that at Toronto and Loudon there are large commons available for field exercises and ranges for practice, these are never used, but the time devoted to squad drills, company and battalion, including all those senseless movements which must be forgotten the moment fighting begins.
X trust the minister will note that these words are not from the man of the active militia, but from a gentleman who has in the past held one of the most distinguished positions in the permanent corps. This appears in the ' Free Press,' a journal supporting the government and it is to he found in last Saturday's issue. In support of my contention as to the manner of discipline from within I might point to our lumber camps. Throughout the length and breadth of northern Ontario there are thousands of men in these lumber camps tonight. There are no fixed bayonets over these men. Yet, you enter one of these camps and you find the order is as perfect as in room 16 or room 6 of this House. And the conduct of these men is just as proper as that of any member of parliament here to-night. Go into any of our railway camps where the roughest men in the community are to be found at work. On a previous occasion I entered into the cost to the country of the certificates given to these officers under the present system, so I shall not take up the time of the House with that to-night. But, I may say that if you figure out the cost for an officer to the Mr. HUGHES (Victoria).
people of Canada-regarding the permanent corps as an educational institution simply- you will find that it amounts to far more than $1,000. One year I found, it amounted to over $3,000 for each certificate. Counting the permanent corps as an educational institution simply, we find that the cost is a little less this year. But I wish to be fair. I do not want to abolish the permanent corps. They have performed good work in connection with the schools and in connection with what you may call police service. And besides they are the nucleus of an army in case we are called upon to defend our frontier. But we must not depend upon this as an army ? We must have throughout the length and breadth of this country men trained for the officer's command and non-com. officers' position, and they must be ready at any moment's notice. And I maintain that this can be done at infinitely less cost and for infinitely greater numbers than under the present system. I again point out that in these schools I would have these men assembled more as they are in colleges and would have the young men treated as free men. I would have them uniformed in a special cadet outfit different from the soldiers, and I would have them perform certain evolutions of drill, ,but I would not have them perform drill that this writer in the * Free Press ' is pleased to call 'absolute rot.' I would not have them waste time with such absolute nonsense as that, but would train them along the lines of a regular college. In that way we could turn out these people at a minimum cost and we should have a proper reserve of Canadian officers.
I shall not enter upon the details of the arguments advanced by those who believe in the intra-mural residence as against the extra-mural, nor upon the points of decorum or etiquette that these young men shouhl learn. There are not many young men from our farms, and I fancy there are still fewer from our towns who could learn much in etiquette from these schools. Take the young men from our farms throughout Canada, today and, as a rule, for everything that makes up real etiquette, they can be placed side by side with our permanent corps officers. That is, even before they are trained. There are not many of them who eat with their knives, and fewer still who peel their potatoes with their fingers in these days. Even if they did these things, it would not take many lessons to teach i! em h< w to act in the company of such Hist" vguish-'d people, and also to impress them with the fact that they should be careful whether tuey pick their teeth with their forks or with their fingers.
Our good friend the editor of the ' Militia Gazette,' in discussing a former debate in this House, took me seriously to task for something which I never said. But I would call attention to toe fact tnat every contention I made on the former occasion as

well as on the one I am making to-night is admitted in the editor's own article. He admits that the schools have very serious defects and are in very great need of reform. And the only thing for which he criticises me is that I am in favour of the young fellows boarding out and attending as cadets rather than being inside and subject to this so-called discipline. I have just procured a fresh certificate, but if Sir John

In Britain to- lay no one wjll gainsay the statement that the British government, in so far as the conduct of this war has been concerned has been more or less powerless in the face of the rings, cabals, sets, and cliques in connection with the army there. I shall illustrate that by reading an extract from the Montreal ' Star,' from the famous article by this Australian writer. Hales, an article which has attained exceedingly large circulation in the old land, and which has
aroused much favourable comment. He says :
We have first of all to purge the British army of abuses, to do away with her old, worn-out rules and regulations. The British home-bred stock constitute the heart of the empire, the heart pumps the blood and vitality through the whole circle of our dominions, and the heart must be pure from taint of all kinds, if the far spreading members are to be free from corruption. To this end, the purification of the lifegiving centres, our energies must be concentrated.
Now, will follow language which, if used in this House by myself, would have been termed extreme and extravagant. But it is written by this officer for the British public and the world public. This is what he says :-
To-day the army of Great Britain is rotten to the core, cliques abound, ' rings ' are rampant, there exist 'circles,' and inside each circle lesser circles revolve in varying degrees of magnetism ; men are made or crushed according to the power of dominant parties, not in accord with personal merit. Read the life history of Colville, Gat-acre and Buller, read the deeds they did for the nation in the field of battle, then turn the page and read their reward-not the reward of the nation, not the reward of the crown they served, but the reward of a clique, the vengeance of a coterie, the venom of a ' ring.'
Let in the Light.
Before we can hope to handle colonial armies satisfactorily, we must purge the * home ' army of all uaoleanllness, we must make it plainly understood that a spirit of unbending justice presides over the destinies of every man who wears the King's uniform, no matter whether he be a simple private or a full-fledged general. The first thing that should be abolished is the system of secret trials. No good thing ever came from behind closed doors-.
Let me urge upon the minister the importance of this matter-never to allow any one to influence him to condemn an officer under him upon a confidential report. I maintain, and I have always acted upon the principle that in the case of every officer in my regiment concerning whom I have sent a confidential report to the minister through the official channel, if it is not absolutely favourable to him he knows exactly what I have written. Never directly or indirectly did I ever send an adverse confidential report.
We Britons oppose that sort of thing in every other walk of life, why do we allow it in our army. If a man is accused of wrong-doing while wearing the King's uniform, let the charge against him' be made publicly, let the witnesses be heard publicly, let him speak in his own defence publicly: then, if he be guiltless, let the shame of a false accusation- fall upon the heads of those who are guilty of making it. If the soldier is guilty then let his disgrace be branded upon him under the gaze of the public, but once and for all time let us stamp out everything that savours of hole-and-corner work, for until this system of secret trial is abolished, no man can be sure of getting even-handed justice. It is useless to argue that an open court for soldiers would damage the service, that argument

can be advanced with just as much force by any other branch of the public service. If secret trials are right and just for the soldier they are just and right for the civilian. We must do away with the ' star chamber ' business, no matter by whom it is upheld : it is a relic of days that are past and gone, and the secret trial must go with the days that spawned it.
These are words that cannot be much better expressed. I shall read now from a famous writer on British constitutional law, Dicey, pointing out the danger that exists in the old land, has always existed, and will always exist in any free governed nation, from a standing army. Dicey says :
A permanent army of paid soldiers, whose main duty is one of absolute obedience to commands, appears at first sight to be an institution inconsistent with that rule of law or submission to the civil authorities, and especially to the judges, which is essential to popular or parliamentary government; and in truth the existence of permanent paid forces has often in most countries, and at times in England-notably under the Commonwealth-been found inconsistent with the existence of what, by a lax though intelligible mode of speech, is called a free government. The belief indeed of our statesmen down to a time considerably later than the revolution of 1689, was that a standing army must be fatal to English freedom, yet very soon after the revolution it became apparent that the existence of a body of paid soldiers was necessary to the safety of the nation. Englishmen therefore, at the end of the seventeenth and the beginning of the eighteenth century, found themselves placed in this dilemma. With a standing army the country could not (they thought) escape from despotism ; without a standing army the country could not (they perceived) escape from invasion ; the maintenance of national liberty appeared to involve the sacrifice of national independence. Yet English statesmanship found almost by accident a practical escape from this theoretical dilemma, and the Mutiny Act, though an enactment passed in a hurry to meet an immediate peril, contains the solution of an apparently insolvable problem.
I want to point out that step by step tbe British war office and its satellites have gradually sought to remove from the Mutiny Act one of the safeguards that it was intended to convey to the free men of England, and we find to-day that the old civil officers of the war office are being dismissed and men under the absolute control of the commander-in-chief are placed in their stead. We find to-day, through the length and breadth of the regular system in England, that this branch of the service has obtained almost supreme control, that it can almost make and unmake governments, and that the Prime Minister himself is almost powerless to resist the influences I have just quoted.
Now, Sir, I have always been a great believer in the militia of a country. It was the militia that won the battles of Cressy, Agincourt and Poitiers In the old days ; it was the militiamen who won the battles of Waterloo and the heights of Alma-because, as I pointed out, a man who is only six Mr. HUGHES (Victoria).
weeks in the army is nothing more than a militiaman. It is men such as these that have won Britain's battles through the long period of her history. Therefore, from various view points, I am greatly in favour of a strong militia force. It is the only way to keep down militarism in a country, it is the only way, under our modern conditions, to defend an empire. Speaking of the militia, Dicey says :
The militia is from its nature a body hardly capable of being used for the purpose of overthrowing parliamentary government. But even with regard to the militia, care has been taken by the legislature to ensure that it shall be subject to the rule of law. The members of the local army are (speaking in general terms) subject to military law only when in training or when the force is embodied. Embodiment indeed converts the militia for the time being into a regular army, though an army which cannot be required to serve abroad. But the embodiment can lawfully take place only in 'case of imminent national danger or of great emergency.'
I would respectfully draw the attention of the minister to the fact that in Canada certain militia officers-I do not refer to the present general officer commanding-have claimed and still claim that an officer of the Canadian militia is at all times subject to the Army Act under the King's regulations. I need not again point out to this House the utter absurdity of any such contention, and I trust the minister will have backbone enough, in framing his new Militia Act, to remove all possible ambiguity upon that point, and that he will lay it down clearly that it is only when militia men are actually called out by Order in Council, or by himself, that they are amenable to the King's regulations and the Army Act. I trust that he will allow nothing in the shape of British red tapeism to influence him in framing his new Militia Act, so that by no possible construction of it will an officer have any control of a junior officer when he is not actually summoned out under the law.
Now, there are a great many weaknesses in any system of a permanent corps, but those, as a rule, are well known to those interested. I may mention, though, that in this country it has been pointed out to us again and again as a thing to be greatly desired that we should do away with civilian control of our militia and place the absolute authority in the hands of tbe general commanding. I have always opposed that, and I incurred the enemity of that great and pious man. General Hutton, on that very ground. That gentleman offered great inducements to many officers to bolster him up in his demands on the minister that he should be made absolutely independent of the minister as regards the discipline and training of the militia of the country. I pointed out to him that this was a responsibly governed country, and that the minister was the only man who should be the master in the premises, that the minister un-

doubtedly should be his master, and that the general should be subject to his control. I may point out that the system which he wanted so much prevails in England; I want to tell you that there to-day, in the British regular army an officer who has a grievance dare not bring it to his superior officer. Under the law he has authority to do so. It has been shown to them again and again that they have the authority, but they will tell you : ' O ! certainly, we know that, but we dare not appeal under the law to our superior officers. The very officers who would pronounce us right in this instance would never forgive us, and they would regard our conduct as insubordinate.' One of these gentlemen who was labouring under considerable disability from a superior officer was asked :	' Then
how do you obtain redress ? ' O ! he said,
' my wife's aunt is a very intimate friend of General Wolseley, she is working the screws and it will come out all right.' There is the way justice is obtained, through rings, cabals and coteries, in the great heart of the British empire to-day. They have men that have given the world liberty, the brave bold men of Runnymede, those who have upheld the honour of the empire all through its history, are reduced to-day to getting their grievances redressed by pettyeoat influence and back door intrigue. I trust sincerely that the minister will not allow any such influences as these to be potent in the Militia Department of Canada, but that he will stand out above all that and treat every one upon his merits and according to the principles of parliamentary government.
I have previously referred to the feeling of Imperial officers towards the Canadian militia. I have before me an extract from the Toronto * Daily Mail ' in which it says :
The story ts an old one, and in the history of soldiering in this country many instances can be cited showing how the air of superiority often displayed by officers in the regular service has beer, the cause of much bad feeling, and has led to an estrangement that has impaired the efficiency of the individuals concerned. Colonel Denison, in his recently published book of renrniscences, has referred to a number of cases in which this peculiar trait in the regular was the cause of annoyance and offence to officers of the Canadian militia, and it is no secret that among the Canadians who have returned from the front there are many who, although they speak with the greatest satisfaction of the relations generally existing between themselves and the regulars declare that their patience was frequently severely taxed in their efforts to preserve amity and concord. It is not necessary to go away from home to find a similar strained relationship, and there is no reason for its existence.
Following upon this we notice that Lord. Roberts, himself, after the shooting of those Australian officers, of which I hope to have something to say on another occasion, was forced to come out and in order to placate the colonials after the gallant stand made
by the Canadians at Kleinhart the other day he issued an order-I have not seen the order but it will not amount to much, I can guarantee that-to which the following has reference :
Unstinted Praise.
London, April 5-The gallantry of the Canadian troops at the engagement with the Boers near Hart's river, South-western Transvaal, March 31, attracts unstinted praise from the British press. Their comments form a striking contrast to the recently printed notification that the attention of Lord Roberts, the commander-in-chief, had been drawn to various cases where colonials who had been awarded commissions were treated as inferiors by the regular officers and otherwise made to feed that they were only members of the mess by sufferance.
Lord Roberts, it was semi-officially announced, was making an investigation and intended to inflict the most serious penalties on any British officers found guilty of such conduct. Privately, and in letters to the press, many colonial officers have frequently complained that ' they are good enough at the front, but are not wanted at a Cape Town hotel or in a London drawing room.'
Personally I have no reason to complain of anything of this sort specially. I chanced to be a senior to most of these gentlemen and with that spirit of sycophancy and fawning, which I regret to say is a characteristic of the British officer, these men are always ready to fawn and cringe before any one who happens to wear an extra star or crown on his shoulder. The tendency of the British officer is towards sycophancy to a great extent but to those who chance to be of junior rank nothing could exceed the superciliousness of the British officer. This must all be changed. The British empire is going to hang together and the British officer must be taught that ithe empire is too great to tolerate conduct of that kind. Great Britain is g'oing to hang together and the supercilious British officer must disappear. The late Cecil Rhodes, after the relief of Kimberley, had the same complaint to make. There were from six to eight thousand brother colonials who did not happen to belong to the British ranks but who were fighting for the empire just as loyally as those in the British ranks were. I am not saying one word against one class or the other. The colonials fell day after day and no notice was taken of them in the lists that were sent out, but when a regular happened to he howled out his death was sure to be properly chronicled in the list. One day mule No. 6217 was chronicled as having departed this life because it belonged to the British regulars in South Africa, but those colonial soldiers who gave up their lives in scores never received a word of notice in the records from the commander in Kimberley at the time. The colonials form an important part of the empire to-day, they are as much interested in the welfare of the empire as the people of the old land, they are prepared to do their part for the maintenance of the em-

pire and it is just as well to give these gentlemen to understand that the army system of Great Britain to-day is not the British empire and it is not fit to stand in connection with the British empire. It is time that it disappeared. In the British organs items are appearing tin the papers now-a-days apologizing for certain victories which were won by the Boers over the British. You cannot point to a victory that the Boers have won in South Africa where, according to the British officer's statement, the British officer was at fault. It was always Tommy, or the yeomanry, or the militia or the colonials. At Belmont, at Modder River, at Magersfontein, at Stormberg, at Spion Kop and at Nicholson's Nek there were no colonials. These disasters occurred and they cannot attribute the blame to the colonials. In this connection I include the British regulars and that type of soldier. We find these British officers coming out and saying : Oh, you know, Tommy is from the slums ; .we can't trust him. He cannot be depended upon. You cannot show an instance in South Africa where Tommy has failed them. They say: We will have to pay him a little more. We will give him a penny a day more, cabbage and some potatoes extra per week. These are the apologies you find from the British officer to-day and the suggestions he makes for building up the great British army. I hope the lion. Minister of Militia and Defence will listen when I say that we must make the system of training British officers inexpensive and one that will develop all that is good and noble in him. I would ask hon. gentlemen not to run away with the notion that what I say applies to all of the British officers. I have given the names of a number of very capable generals who have distinguished themselves. I would ask hon. gentlemen not to run away with the notion that all these British officers are of the lawdy-daw type-not by any means. There are hundreds of these fellows who would, if they were allowed by the system, devote their attention to the upbuilding of their forces, so as to make themselves fit and proper men to lead their fellowmen in battle. Men intrusted with the lives of their fellow-* men should be properly trained and there are hundreds of these young British officers who would only be too anxious to improve their opportunities and their usefulness were it not that the system of repression, regimental messing and club work in connection with this institution drives the young man out of his regiment or forces him into a groove and he becomes a fit subject to be described by what is a general term in the old country a Piccadilly dude. At the beginning of this war General French, a man who has distinguished himself in South Africa, and who has never met with a reverse, was placed on the retired list because he did not happen to be of the school that happened to be dominant at the time. Many

another good officer was placed where he would be of no use to his country until the stern needs of time brought him back again. Now, I have gone into this matter at more or less length but there are a few items which I have now here and which I propose discussing but which I will reserve until we come to the consideration of the supplementary estimates when we will have the opportunity of entering into the subject at greater detail than we will here to-night. I could refer to extract after extract from the leading newspapers of the country in support of the views that I have upheld here to-night- not only Canadian but English. I shall quote a brief extract from an article written by the Rev. Dr. G. M. Milligan, referring to a visit he paid to England last year. He said :
I found quite prevalent in Britain the feeling that social favouritism is responsible for much hurt done in military matters. Unfortunately the evil is not dead against which Carlyle declaimed when he wrote. Where now are your Hengists and Horsas shooting partridges ! '
' The flannelled fools ' are those who make pleasure a finality of their lives. Such are a danger to any community, when they affect to discharge important functions.
I could quote scores of articles from the leading editorials published in the best English newspapers, among them the ' London Times ' itself, a paper which is most favourable, as every one knows, to Mr. Chamberlain and Sir Alfred Milner in regard to the conduct of that war, but I have done enough to show that there is need of a revolution and that the old system of red tape must disappear and that British officers must be properly trained. We have the rifle shooting and the manouvering. These must of necessity be retained, but we must adopt some cheap system of training our officers and the only cheap system possible is the one I have pointed out. Star chamber methods must vanish. All these cabals and rings and sets ; political influence and stock gambling favours and their attendant weaknesses must be banished from the training of the British officer. The manhood of the old land must reassert itself, and in case that one department of the British army, the combatant officers training, is reformed, then the old empire will be in a position to deal with the world.
Go tell the world our watchword low,
Let deep proclaim to deep.
The crown that shines on Edward's brow,
His sons right hands will keep.
The empire that our fathers won Will still ha greater yet.
And on it as o'er shines the sun No sun shall ever set.
The (MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE (Hon. F. W. Borden). I am sure the House has listened, as I have, with a great deal of pleasure, to the very interesting address of my hon. and gallant friend

(Mr. Hughes). I had no idea, I am bound to confess, that the hon. gentleman's remarks would take such a very wide range. It would really seem as if his speech was one to be replied to by Mr. Broderick, the British Secretary for War, and not by the Canadian Minister of Militia, because his strictures were very much more severe upon the British army system than upon ours.
I presume that my hon. friend was endeavouring to illustrate what he considers to be the evils of the conditions which he disapproved of in Canada, by the effect of them on Great Britain; more particularly in the conduct of the war in South Africa. However, the House will hardly expect me to undertake the task of defending the conduct of that war from the British point of view. I was glad that my hon. friend was able to admit that in so far, at any rate, as the work done by the non-combatant or civil branch of the army in South Africa was concerned, he thought it was admirable, and indeed that it could not have been better. I entirely agree with the hon. gentleman in that. 1 would be inclined to go further. Although I confess I am not a judge of such matters, aud have not had the advantage that the hon. gentleman (Mr. Hughes) has had of being on the ground, X would be inclined to hazard the statement that no nation in the world could have coped with the serious difficulties which the British nation has had to meet in South Africa, as ably as Great Britain has done. That is my opinion after having given the matter as careful attention ns I have been able to. That mistakes, and grave mistakes, have been made there cannot be a question. But in the main, and -in view of circumstances of the most extraordinary difficulty, I think the campaign has been well conducted.
My hon. friend (Mr. Hughes) finds fault with my having stated on a former occasion, that the observations he made on a kindred subject meant that he would wipe out the permanent force altogether. I did not intend to say that. What I intended to say was this : That the arguments which the hon. gentleman used were arguments which any one might use against the continuance of a permanent force, and I think any impartial listener to the statements made by the hon. gentleman to-day could draw no other conclusion from his arguments than that they were addressed against the system of standing armies and the system of permanent corps ; although he did say that he was favourable to the continuation of the permanent force in this country.
To come at once to the consideration of the question which more particularly directly concerns us, let me say a few words with refernce to our permanent force. Without making this in any way an excuse for existing conditions, if excuse be necessary, let me .first say. that the permanent force
has been in existence in this country for a good many years; long before I became Minister of Militia, that the very officers who are outside of the permanent force to-day and from whose writings my hon. friend has quoted, were members of the permanent force not so very long ago; spent many years in it; passed through it and came out of it without apparently having discovered, while in the force, the necessity for any great reform. It is only after they left the force that they were prepared to make criticism ot it. It seems to me that it would have been very much better for them to have addressed these observations during the time they were in the force, to their superior officers, and if they could not get their ear to have endeavoured to get the ear of the minister'of the day.

Will the minister permit me ? The officer who is outside of the permanent force to-day and who was formerly in it, defends the system. I hope I was not misunderstood in that. All the time that officer was in the force he took the very same ground that he takes to-day and did not hesitate to let it be known. The other officer to whom I refer, I think, is in the permanent force to-day, and is one of the best men in it. I may be wrong in that, but at all events I do not want to get that officer into any trouble.
The	MINISTER	OF	MILITIA	AND
DEFENCE. I think I know the officer to whom the hon. gentleman refers.

That officer is one of the best men in the force.
The	MINISTER	OF	MILITIA	ANDDEFENCE. He is an able man, but I think he is a bit of a faddist and somewhat extreme. As to the condition of the permanent force I must take issue with my hon. friend on the picture which he drew of life in the barracks. He compared the existing conditions in the barracks of the permanent force in Canada to the conditions in a prison. I dissent absolutely	and entirely	from that statement.I have had the pleasure of visiting all the depots in Canada except that at Winnipeg. I have been in the men's rooms ; have seen them getting their food, have	been through the hospitals,	have
seen the men at their games, in their reading rooms, and I must say that I never met anywhere a more contented set of men than are to be found in our permanent force so far as appearances go, and so far as my observation could lead me to form an opinion. I have heard no complaints. The men of the permanent force in this country are nverage Canadians. They enjoyed perfect freedom before they went into the force; they know perfectly well what the laws and customs of this country are. and they have scores of friends outside of the force who, if they were being ill-used, would very soon make the fact known to the minister, or to

some superior officer. Nothing of this kind so far as I know has taken place, and it is therefore fair to assume that there is no serious grievance of the kind to which my hon. friend (Mr. Hughes) referred. I think that the vivid imagination which my hon. friend possesses led him a step too far. If he had been content to stop at the point, which I think he was endeavouring to make: That the military system now in vogue in Great Britain and in the permanent force in this country, has a tendency to narrow a man's mind and ideas, X would be very much inclined to think that there was some force in what he said.
When my hon. friend says that there was a deliberate attempt to enslave the members of the permanent corps he is going entirely too far. We must not forget that in the British army and in the permanent force of Canada there is no conscription. The citizens of both countries are absolutely free to enlist or not, so that the system is entirely different from that on the continent of Europe, where conscription is the order of the day. It is not at all likely that men would voluntarily enter a system where they become enslaved. My hon. friend has found fault with the permanent corps because, he says, it takes too long for an officer to become qualified under our regulations. He seems to think that a man who wishes to become an officer has to attend different depots and different schools. If I remember right, this is not the case. An infantry officer can go to Toronto and become fully qualified, including the course of equitation, in from four to eight weeks, according to his ability and previous knowledge. I do not see any great hardship in that. A cavalry officer can do the same and so can an artillery officer in Kingston or Quebec. This objection of my hon. friend therefore is not well founded.
He also says that the cost to the country of every certificate to every officer in Canada each year is about $1,000. I have not made the calculation and am not prepared to dispute his statement. If he takes the total amount of money spent upon the permanent corps and divides it by the number of commissions issued, I do not know what that will give for I have not made the calculation.
It was over $3,000 two years and it is now $2,000.
But my hon. friend must not forget the work these depots are doing in the way of garrison duty.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: Did I not point that out ?

The statement I took down was that each certificate cost so much money. But we should give the permanent force credit for the work done in garrisoning the Hon. Mr. BORDEN (King's).
different cities or places where these depots are located, and we must not forget also that these different depots are really the nuclei of an army in the case of sudden attack from within or without.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext: I have pointed that out.

Then we agree on that point. My hon. friend referred to the permanent force officers' treatment of the men who come in from the country districts and take a course at the depots. I assure him that any such conduct as he describes, I should condemn quite as strongly as he. Possibly some weak-minded members of the permanent force may be inclined to act in that way.
Ml-. HUGHES (Victoria). They do it not only to those who come in from the country, but to those who are their superiors in knowledge and position and everything else in this country except military rank.
The MINISTER OF* MILITIA AND DEFENCE. If they do, it is a very strong indication that there heads are not very well balanced. I should hope that only a small percentage of the officers are guilty of any such contemptible conduct. Whenever I have had opportunity to visit the depots,
I have always tried to point out to the permanent force officers that they are militia the same as all the rest, the only difference being that they are paid for their whole time and are expected to give the best of their time and ability to the improvement and assistance of their brother officers in the country districts. That is the true spirit which should animate the force, and I hope it is that which animates the majority. Because, we can never get the most out of the permanent corps, we can never really have an effective militia unless there is the strongest bond of sympathy between the permanent force and the active militia. The very reason d'etre of a permanent force is to help along and support the active militia. Otherwise there would have been no permanent force thought of.
As my hon. friend has explained his object in bringing up this resolution and as I have assured him that I shall give the greatest attention to his many valuable suggestions, and in view of the statement I have had the honour to make, and of which he has no doubt seen an outline in the press, with reference to proposed changes,
I trust he will consent to withdraw his motion and wait another year, when, if we have not profited by the discussion which has taken place this afternoon, he can renew It.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext:
I warned the House when I began that I was likely to be misunderstood, and apparently have been so incoherent that my good friend the Min-

ister of Militia has completely misunderstood the views which I submitted to the House. He says that Mr. Broderick the English Minister of War would have beeu the one to reply to the strictures I made. But I pointed out that all the evils of the British service were being grafted on our Canadian system; and in criticising the Imperial army, I was simply aiming at the fountain head of all the iniquity. I cordially agree with my hon. friend, and so stated that Britain has no equal in the conduct of a war such as that in South Africa. I believe there is no nation in the world which possibly could have placed the men there she did in the field, feed them and maintain them there, but the mere fact that the men are well clothed and fed is no excuse for the incapacity of generals or officers, and is no reason why our soldiers should be buried in South Africa and the nation left to mourn their loss. Let the men be well fed, by all means, and well clad, but also see that they get the best of the enemy instead of the reverse, which has too often been the case in South Africa. My hon. friend took exception to my comparing the permanent force to a prison. I did not say that the discipline was exactly the same. I admit that it has a little advantage but not much over the modern system of discipline in an ordinary prison. But I say that in no other institutions, except prisons and the British and Canadian permanent forces, are men treated as they are, owing to the military discipline enforced in these services.
The minister spoke of the men in the permanent force being contented and happy. Well, the reply which he gave to a question I put to him not very long ago does not bear out his statement. I, asked how 'many courts-martial there have been in the corps, and the hon. gentleman told me that there were nearly two in the year for every man in the permanent corps and that the number of minor punishments numbered away up in the thousands. And this is in a force of a few hundred men. I fail to see how that force can be well governed or happy when courts-martial and punishments are so numerous. In a school where the teacher has to wallop, on a average, each youngster three times a year there is something radically wrong with his discipline or with himself. The youngsters are always all right. Then, this takes no account of the number of desertions and the number of men who are up for petty punishments, for they are not recorded. Now, the minister puts words into my mouth that I believe I did not utter -certainly did not intend to utter. He would have hon. members believe I said there was an aim on the part of the permanent corps officers to enslave the men. The permanent corps officers are merely carrying out the dark-age traditions respecting the management of men, that have been handed down from generation to generation.
And it has applied to all types of humanity. It is the only kind of discipline they know, poor fellows. Many of them, I have no doubt, would prefer carrying out a proper system of discipline, if they had been instructed in it rather than his repressive system. Then the minister refers to the point that it takes an officer too long to become qualified. But he must remember that, before an officer can go up for his certificate, he must have his non-coms' or private's instructions. He must come here for his musketry, he must go elsewhere for his signalling, somewhere else for his equitation and somewhere else for his maxim gun drill. My object would be to so arrange it that when a cadet comes up-and he would come merely as a young citizen of Canada-he could get the training at whatever place he was. And, moreover, he would be free to enter the school at any time he pleased, and not be obliged to await the whim of any officer in command. I shall not refer to the other matters touched upon by the hon. minister, as they are of no consequence. He agrees as to the cost of certificates, but I was particular to point out that in addition to doing educational duty, these corps performed police duty and also form the nuclei of a standing army for the defence of the country in case they should be called on.
Motion withdrawn.
